label: [statemachine] Representing gen_statem in Erlang-Red
info: ## gen_statem behaviour Erlang-Red won't be Erlang if it didn't know how to behave itself. This example shows how the [gen_statem](https://www.erlang.org/doc/apps/stdlib/gen_statem.html) behaviour can be visually implemented in Erlang-Red. ## Setup Setting up a state machine requires defining a module for defining the behaviour of the state machine. For this test, the Module: pushbutton is being used. It represents the [push pen button example](https://www.erlang.org/doc/apps/stdlib/gen_statem.html#module-pushbutton-code) from the documentation of the state machine. The state machine nodes make reference to the module in their respective configurations. That defines the statemachines behaviour. When the statemachine receives a message from the one of the inject nodes, it calls executes the follwing: ```erlang #{payload := Action} = Msg, Result = gen_statem:call(Pid, binary_to_atom(Action)), ``` The `payload` defines the action to perform and the result of the action is passed out as the payload on the outgoing message - if an outgoing message is generated. ## Option: Send on state change The difference between the two examples is that the top one only emits an outgoing message if the state has changed. This does not happen when `get_count` is triggered - it does not result in a state change so there is no outgoing message generated. The bottom example always emits outgoing messages, generating a message on every action. Using this options allows the statemachine to act as a gateway. ## Current state The current state of the statemachine is always shown on the status of the node. ## Other behaviours - [Supervisor](https://flows.red-erik.org/f/83c5e1824f32abec) - [Event Handler](https://flows.red-erik.org/f/b70a7ce34819e4d5)

name: only emit message on state change
common code used by all examples here
State machine - don't send on same state
Module: pushbutton
code:
%%
%% Inspired by
%%  https://www.erlang.org/doc/apps/stdlib/gen_statem.html#module-pushbutton-code
%%
-module(pushbutton).
-behaviour(gen_statem).

-export([
    start/0,
    init/1,
    callback_mode/0,
    handle_event/4,
    code_change/4,
    terminate/3,
    stop/0
]).

callback_mode() -> handle_event_function.

-define(KEEP_STATE(ReplyWith),
    {keep_state, Data, [{reply, From, ReplyWith}]}
).

start() ->
    gen_statem:start({local, ?MODULE}, ?MODULE, [], []).

stop() ->
    gen_statem:stop(?MODULE).
terminate(_Reason, _State, _Data) ->
    void.
code_change(_Vsn, State, Data, _Extra) ->
    {ok, State, Data}.

%% Initial state and data
init([]) ->
    State = off, 
    Data = 0,
    {ok,State,Data}.

%%% state callback(s)

handle_event(
  {call, From},
  <<"push">>,
  off,
  Data
) ->
    {next_state, on, Data + 1, [{reply, From, <<"ok">>}]};

handle_event(
  {call, From},
  <<"push">>,
  on,
  Data
) ->
    {next_state, off, Data, [{reply, From, <<"ok">>}]};

handle_event(
  {call, From},
  <<"get_count">>,
  _CurrState,
  Data
) ->
    {keep_state, Data, [{reply, From, Data}]};

%%
%% Fall through.
handle_event({call, From} = EventType, Stiff, State, Data) ->
    io:format("TEST (call): ~p ~p ~p ~p~n",[EventType, Stiff, State, Data]),
    ?KEEP_STATE(<<"not_allowed">>);

handle_event(EventType, Stiff, State, Data) ->
    io:format("TEST : ~p ~p ~p ~p~n",[EventType, Stiff, State, Data]),
    {keep_state, Data}.
